head.title: Texaco Reports Progress In Minority Hiring

hedline.hl1: Texaco Reports Progress In Minority Hiring

abstract.p: Texaco, in keeping with 1996 court order, releases report indicating minorities made up 44 percent of all new hires in 1999, an increase of minority workers from from 22.1 percent to 22.4 percent (S)

block.p: Texaco increased the number of minorities in its work force last year, exceeding goals set in the wake of a 1996 racial discrimination lawsuit, according to a new report filed at the Federal District Court in White Plains.

Minorities made up 44 percent of all new hires in 1999, pushing the total percentage of minority employees from 22.1 percent to 22.4 percent. The company also laid off about 2,500 employees worldwide last year after a downturn in the oil industry, including 150 positions at its White Plains headquarters.

Texaco increased the number of minorities in its work force last year, exceeding goals set in the wake of a 1996 racial discrimination lawsuit, according to a new report filed at the Federal District Court in White Plains.

Minorities made up 44 percent of all new hires in 1999, pushing the total percentage of minority employees from 22.1 percent to 22.4 percent. The company also laid off about 2,500 employees worldwide last year after a downturn in the oil industry, including 150 positions at its White Plains headquarters.

The report was released by the Texaco Task Force on Equality and Fairness, an independent panel created as part of Texaco's settlement of a federal class action lawsuit filed by African-American employees. Texaco settled the case for a record $176 million.
